htmlEmbed:
‘Unusual’ cancers emerged after the pandemic. Doctors ask if covid is to blame.Ariana Eunjung Cha6/6/2024

It’s not a new idea that viruses can cause or accelerate cancer. But it will probably be years before answers emerge about covid and cancer.

HealthRead

data-testid="drop-cap-letter" data-apitype="text" data-contentid="5GP33XISTFGSVGQCSLQ3MN7MSI" data-el="text" class="wpds-c-heFNVF wpds-c-heFNVF-iPJLV-css overrideStyles font-copy" dir="null">ROCK HILL, S.C. — Kashyap Patel looked forward to his team’s Friday lunches. All the doctors from his oncology practice would gather in the open-air courtyard under the shadow of a tall magnolia tree and catch up. The atmosphere tended to the lighthearted and optimistic. But that week, he was distressed.</p></div></div><div></div><div class="wpds-c-PJLV article-body" data-qa="article-body"></div><div class="wpds-c-PJLV article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-testid="drop-cap-letter" data-apitype="text" data-contentid="6RTNG6QDX5E65LIJ7YOLRQ3YGU" data-el="text" class="wpds-c-heFNVF wpds-c-heFNVF-iPJLV-css overrideStyles font-copy" dir="null">It was 2021, a year into the <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/coronavirus/?itid=lk_inline_manual_4" target="_blank" class="contextual_link">coronavirus</a> pandemic, and as he slid into a chair, Patel shared that he’d just seen a patient in his 40s with cholangiocarcinoma, a rare and lethal cancer of the bile ducts that typically strikes people in their 70s and 80s. Initially, there was silence, and then one colleague after another said they’d recently treated patients who had similar diagnoses. Within a year of that meeting, the office had recorded seven such cases.</p></div><div class="wpds-c-PJLV article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-testid="drop-cap-letter" data-apitype="text" data-contentid="UZT7FI5LRZDFRDWVEOKZDWVF5U" data-el="text" class="wpds-c-heFNVF wpds-c-heFNVF-iPJLV-css overrideStyles font-copy" dir="null">“I’ve been in practice 23 years and have never seen anything like this,” Patel, CEO of Carolina Blood and Cancer Care Associates, later recalled. Asutosh Gor, another oncologist, agreed: “We were all shaken.”</p></div><div class="wpds-c-PJLV wpds-c-PJLV-bHCGeL-isStandardLayoutAd-true article-body" data-qa="article-body"><div class="cb dn db-ns" data-qa="article-body-ad" data-testid="article-body-ad-desktop"><div aria-hidden="true" class="hide-for-print relative flex justify-center content-box items-center b bh mb-md mt-none pt-lg pb-lg" article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-testid="drop-cap-letter" data-apitype="text" data-contentid="XJ5ONUNUXBGVPI5VLQ65EV7PCI" data-el="text" class="wpds-c-heFNVF wpds-c-heFNVF-iPJLV-css overrideStyles font-copy" dir="null">There was other weirdness, too: multiple patients contending with multiple types of cancer arising almost simultaneously, and more than a dozen new cases of other rare cancers.</p></div><div class="wpds-c-PJLV article-body" data-qa="article-body"></div><div class="wpds-c-PJLV article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-testid="drop-cap-letter" data-apitype="text" data-contentid="6JIPCV5X5RD2TBWD5O2SGLBH7I" data-el="text" class="wpds-c-heFNVF wpds-c-heFNVF-iPJLV-css overrideStyles font-copy" dir="null">Increasingly, Patel was left with an unsettling thought: Could the coronavirus be inflaming<b> </b>the embers of cancer?</p></div><div class="wpds-c-PJLV article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-testid="drop-cap-letter" data-apitype="text" data-contentid="GCITCWGVTJBMRPGN6WUUQZIVS4" data-el="text" class="wpds-c-heFNVF wpds-c-heFNVF-iPJLV-css overrideStyles font-copy" dir="null">The uptick in aggressive, late-stage cancers since the dawn of the pandemic is confirmed by some early national data and a number of large cancer institutions. Many experts have mostly dismissed the trend as an expected consequence of disruptions to health care that began in 2020.</p></div><div class="wpds-c-PJLV article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-testid="drop-cap-letter" data-apitype="text" data-contentid="7GJTV6SRJZDW3HGQQWY5J2BDHU" data-el="text" class="wpds-c-heFNVF wpds-c-heFNVF-iPJLV-css overrideStyles font-copy" dir="null">But not everyone.</p></div><div class="wpds-c-PJLV article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-testid="drop-cap-letter" data-apitype="text" data-contentid="FSN6IPU7DBDSNLJVZK43ZDQM74" data-el="text" class="wpds-c-heFNVF wpds-c-heFNVF-iPJLV-css overrideStyles font-copy" dir="null">The idea that some viruses can cause or accelerate cancer is hardly new. Scientists have recognized this possibility since the 1960s, and today, researchers estimate 15 to 20 percent of all cancers worldwide originate from infectious agents such as HPV, Epstein-Barr and hepatitis B.</p></div><div class="wpds-c-PJLV wpds-c-PJLV-bHCGeL-isStandardLayoutAd-true article-body" data-qa="article-body"><div class="cb dn db-ns" data-qa="article-body-ad" data-testid="article-body-ad-desktop"><div aria-hidden="true" class="hide-for-print relative flex justify-center content-box items-center b bh mb-md mt-none pt-lg pb-lg" style="min-height:250px"><div data-qa="article-body"><div class="cb db dn-ns" data-qa="article-body-ad" data-testid="article-body-ad-mobile"><div aria-hidden="true" class="hide-for-print relative flex justify-center content-box items-center b bh mb-md mt-sm pt-sm pb-sm ad-mobile" style="min-height:250px;border-top-color:transparent;border-bottom-color:transparent"><div class="center absolute w-100 border-box"><div class="dib gray-dark pl-xs pr-xs font-sans-serif light font-xxxxs lh-md" style="--primary-border-color:var(--wpds-colors-alpha25)"></div></div><div data-testid="placeholder-box" class="w-100 h-100 absolute flex lh-md"></div></div></div></div></div><div class="wpds-c-PJLV article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-testid="drop-cap-letter" data-apitype="text" data-contentid="MGADNGJBRBFFFEQLHTAC7OAEHA" data-el="text" class="wpds-c-heFNVF wpds-c-heFNVF-iPJLV-css overrideStyles font-copy" dir="null">It will probably be many years before the world has conclusive answers about whether the coronavirus is complicit in the surge of cancer cases, but Patel and other concerned scientists are calling on the U.S. government to make this question a priority knowing it could affect treatment and management of millions of cancer patients for decades to come.</p></div><div class="wpds-c-PJLV article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-testid="drop-cap-letter" data-apitype="text" data-contentid="OAJBVGHGV5HYFK6YSJZ5FNCIDQ" data-el="text" class="wpds-c-heFNVF wpds-c-heFNVF-iPJLV-css overrideStyles font-copy" dir="null">“We are completely under-investigating this virus,” said Douglas C. Wallace, a University of Pennsylvania geneticist and evolutionary biologist. “The effects of repeatedly getting this throughout our lives is going to be much more significant than people are thinking.”</p></div><div class="wpds-c-PJLV article-body" data-qa="article-body"><div class="PJLV PJLV-iPJLV-css hide-for-print" data-qa="article-image"><div style="min-height:358px"></div></div></div><div class="wpds-c-PJLV article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-testid="drop-cap-letter" data-apitype="text" data-contentid="A3IKXRAEBREQ5GGZN2EHIR35LM" data-el="text" class="wpds-c-heFNVF wpds-c-heFNVF-iPJLV-css overrideStyles font-copy" dir="null">But there is no real world data linking SARS-CoV-2 to cancer, and some scientists remain<b> </b>skeptical.</p></div><div class="wpds-c-PJLV wpds-c-PJLV-bHCGeL-isStandardLayoutAd-true article-body" data-qa="article-body"><div class="cb db dn-ns" data-qa="article-body-ad" data-testid="article-body-ad-mobile"><div aria-hidden="true" class="hide-for-print relative flex justify-center content-box items-center b bh mb-md mt-sm pt-sm pb-sm ad-mobile" style="min-height:250px;border-top-color:transparent;border-bottom-color:transparent"><div class="center absolute w-100 border-box"><div class="dib gray-dark pl-xs pr-xs font-sans-serif light font-xxxxs lh-md" style="--primary-border-color:var(--wpds-colors-alpha25)"></div></div><div data-testid="placeholder-box" class="w-100 h-100 absolute flex flex-column justify-center border-box bg-offwhite" style="width:300px;height:250px"><div class="flex flex-column justify-center font-sans-serif center font-xxs light gray-dark lh-md"></div></div></div></div></div><div class="wpds-c-PJLV article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-testid="drop-cap-letter" data-apitype="text" data-contentid="6Q7H63VHPVGETGCJL4W75UKBCI" data-el="text" class="wpds-c-heFNVF wpds-c-heFNVF-iPJLV-css overrideStyles font-copy" dir="null">John T. Schiller, a National Institutes of Health researcher and pioneer in the study of cancer-causing viruses, said pathogens known to cause cancer persist in the body long-term. But the class of respiratory viruses that includes influenza and RSV — a family that counts the coronavirus as a member — infects a patient and then typically goes away instead of lingering and is not believed to cause cancer.</p></div><div class="wpds-c-PJLV wpds-c-PJLV-bHCGeL-isStandardLayoutAd-true article-body" data-qa="article-body"><div class="cb dn db-ns" data-qa="article-body-ad" data-testid="article-body-ad-desktop"><div aria-hidden="true" class="hide-for-print relative flex justify-center content-box items-center b bh mb-md mt-none pt-lg pb-lg" style="min-height:250px"><div class="center absolute w-100 border-box"><div class="dib gray-dark pl-xs pr-xs font-sans-serif light font-xxxxs lh-md" style="--primary-border-color:var(--wpds-colors-alpha25)"></div></div><div data-testid="placeholder-box" class="w-100 h-100 absolute flex flex-column justify-center border-box bg-offwhite" style="width:300px;height:250px"><div class="flex flex-column justify-center font-sans-serif center font-xxs light gray-dark lh-md"><div>Advertisement</div></div></div></div></div></div><div class="wpds-c-PJLV article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-testid="drop-cap-letter" data-apitype="text" data-contentid="Y6V7PAEEFNEBDNKMZEBR2NAPV4" data-el="text" class="wpds-c-heFNVF wpds-c-heFNVF-iPJLV-css overrideStyles font-copy" dir="null">“You can never say never, but that sort of … virus does not suggest being implicated in cancers,” Schiller said.</p></div><div class="wpds-c-PJLV article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-testid="drop-cap-letter" data-apitype="text" data-contentid="BPK3AF7PSZDR5BAFBRV7B6PEGM" data-el="text" class="wpds-c-heFNVF wpds-c-heFNVF-iPJLV-css overrideStyles font-copy" dir="null">David Tuveson, director of the Cancer Center at Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory and former president of the American Association for Cancer Research, said there’s no evidence the coronavirus directly transforms cells to make them cancerous. But that may not be the full story.</p></div><div class="wpds-c-PJLV wpds-c-PJLV-bHCGeL-isStandardLayoutAd-true article-body" data-qa="article-body"><div class="cb db dn-ns" data-qa="article-body-ad" overrideStyles font-copy" dir="null">Tuveson said a number of small and early studies — many of which have been published within the past nine months — suggests that coronavirus infection can induce an inflammatory cascade and other responses that, in theory, could exacerbate the growth of cancer cells.</p></div><div class="wpds-c-PJLV article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-testid="drop-cap-letter" data-apitype="text" data-contentid="V7BQVFU3UNBXHIQMX6IK6P6FR4" data-el="text" class="wpds-c-heFNVF wpds-c-heFNVF-iPJLV-css overrideStyles font-copy" dir="null">He has wondered whether it could be more akin to an environmental stressor — like tobacco, alcohol, asbestos or microplastics.</p></div><div class="wpds-c-PJLV article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-testid="drop-cap-letter" data-apitype="text" data-contentid="ESYYTSTBBVCEHFO7GG6WKFUBRA" data-el="text" class="wpds-c-heFNVF wpds-c-heFNVF-iPJLV-css overrideStyles font-copy" dir="null">“Covid wrecks the body, and that’s where cancers can start,” Tuveson said, explaining how autopsy studies of people who died of covid-19 showed prematurely aged tissue.</p></div><div class="wpds-c-PJLV late-stage cancers.</p></div><div class="wpds-c-PJLV wpds-c-PJLV-bHCGeL-isStandardLayoutAd-true article-body" data-qa="article-body"><div class="cb db dn-ns" data-qa="article-body-ad" overrideStyles font-copy" dir="null">Xuesong Han, scientific director of health services research at the American Cancer Society and lead author of the Lancet Oncology study, attributed the jump to people delaying or skipping care because of fears related to the virus or because of economic reasons and also to cultural factors, language barriers and discrimination. But Han acknowledged that biological mechanisms of SARS-CoV-2, the virus that causes covid-19, could be at play.</p></div><div class="wpds-c-PJLV article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-testid="drop-cap-letter" data-apitype="text" data-contentid="ITVV5ZZNFFHDXNWMPRVRXUP4TA" data-el="text" class="wpds-c-heFNVF wpds-c-heFNVF-iPJLV-css overrideStyles font-copy" dir="null">“I don’t have the data to support this opinion,” Han said. “But it’s an important question to follow up on.”</p></div><div class="wpds-c-PJLV article-body" data-qa="article-body"><h3 data-qa="article-header" data-contentid="UYWREWS5FFCDBFGOLNJWWIAMHI" data-apitype="header" class=" pb-sm pt-lgmod" id="UYWREWS5FFCDBFGOLNJWWIAMHI"><div>‘Hopefully, we’re wrong’</div></h3></div><div class="wpds-c-PJLV article-body" data-qa="article-body"><div class="PJLV PJLV-iPJLV-css hide-for-print" data-qa="article-image"><div style="min-height:358px"></div></div></div><div class="wpds-c-PJLV article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-testid="drop-cap-letter" data-apitype="text" data-contentid="ONWM27UH55GRVKRPNBLSEQTIAI" data-el="text" class="wpds-c-heFNVF wpds-c-heFNVF-iPJLV-css overrideStyles font-copy" dir="null">The human body is made up of trillions of cells in a constant state of growth, repair and death. Most of the time, cells with damaged DNA fix themselves, or simply disappear. Sometimes, they start collecting mistakes in their genetic code and rampage out of control into tumors, destroying parts of the body.</p></div><div class="wpds-c-PJLV overrideStyles font-copy" dir="null">Afshin Beheshti is president of the COVID-19 International Research Team, a group of scientists from eclectic backgrounds who got together during the pandemic to consider out-of-the-box of ways to tackle the virus. Beheshti’s background is in cancer biology, and he said that as the science on the virus evolved — including studies showing widespread inflammation following infection, impact on the vascular system and infection in multiple organs vulnerable to cancer stem cell development — he kept thinking “the signals seemed to be related to early cancer changes.”</p></div><div class="wpds-c-PJLV article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-testid="drop-cap-letter" data-apitype="text" data-contentid="RCTSW3PXLNCMRM7F2AWOKZYD7Q" data-el="text" class="wpds-c-heFNVF wpds-c-heFNVF-iPJLV-css Harvard’s Broad Institute, reached out to Patel, who is a past president of the Community Oncology Alliance, a national group of independent cancer specialists, and they hosted a symposium with other scientists that concluded compelling evidence exists suggesting links between the coronavirus and cancer.</p></div><div class="wpds-c-PJLV wpds-c-PJLV-bHCGeL-isStandardLayoutAd-true article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-testid="drop-cap-letter" data-apitype="text" data-contentid="UUU4DH2V6BBT5CFDNIQYDA76GA" data-el="text" class="wpds-c-heFNVF wpds-c-heFNVF-iPJLV-css overrideStyles overrideStyles font-copy" dir="null">And a University of Colorado team is studying whether covid reawakens dormant cancer cells in mice. Their provocative findings, according to a <a href="https://www.researchsquare.com/article/rs-4210090/v1" target=_blank>preprint</a> report released in April, showed that when mice that were cancer survivors were infected with SARS-CoV-2, dormant cancer cells proliferated in the lungs. They saw similar results with the flu virus.</p></div><div class="wpds-c-PJLV wpds-c-PJLV-bHCGeL-isStandardLayoutAd-true article-body" data-qa="article-body"><div class="cb dn db-ns" wpds-c-heFNVF-iPJLV-css overrideStyles font-copy" dir="null">Ashani Weeraratna, a professor at the Johns Hopkins Bloomberg School of Public Health, said the Colorado study, which she did not participate in, is part of a new field of work that emerged during the past decade that drills into what stimuli can reawaken cancer cells.</p></div><div class="wpds-c-PJLV article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-testid="drop-cap-letter" data-apitype="text" data-contentid="DJDQQ74ABRGIHCAEIKBDMDEDA4" data-el="text" class="wpds-c-heFNVF wpds-c-heFNVF-iPJLV-css overrideStyles font-copy" dir="null">She said it is consistent with research highlighting the importance of the immune system in activating cells from dormancy, so it makes sense that “something like influenza or covid that triggers inflammation could change in the immune microenvironment.” But the results surprised her because “it’s rare the data are so striking.”</p></div><div class="wpds-c-PJLV article-body" data-qa="article-body"><div class="PJLV PJLV-iPJLV-css hide-for-print" data-qa="article-image"><div style="min-height:358px"></div></div></div><div class="wpds-c-PJLV article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-testid="drop-cap-letter" data-apitype="text" data-contentid="M2TFQPUNFFDIFA7QTKL4BHUFDQ" data-el="text" class="wpds-c-heFNVF wpds-c-heFNVF-iPJLV-css overrideStyles font-copy" dir="null">Weeraratna said that while she believes the Colorado study’s findings are important, they should be interpreted with caution. Studies in mice often do not translate to human experiences. She said it’s also important to emphasize that the research and other recent papers focusing on covid and cancer involve acute infection or long covid; they do not suggest a link between the coronavirus vaccine and cancer — misinformation that some anti-vaccine groups have spread in recent months.</p></div><div class="wpds-c-PJLV wpds-c-PJLV-bHCGeL-isStandardLayoutAd-true article-body" data-qa="article-body"><div class="cb dn db-ns" data-qa="article-body-ad" data-testid="article-body-ad-desktop"><div aria-hidden="true" class="hide-for-print relative flex justify-center content-box items-center b bh mb-md mt-none pt-lg pb-lg" style="min-height:250px"><div class="center absolute w-100 border-box"><div class="dib gray-dark pl-xs pr-xs font-sans-serif light font-xxxxs lh-md" style="--primary-border-color:var(--wpds-colors-alpha25)"></div></div><div data-testid="placeholder-box" class="w-100 h-100 absolute flex flex-column justify-center border-box bg-offwhite" style="width:300px;height:250px"><div class="flex flex-column justify-center font-sans-serif center font-xxs light gray-dark lh-md"><div>Advertisement</div></div></div></div></div></div><div class="wpds-c-PJLV article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-testid="drop-cap-letter" data-apitype="text" data-contentid="OTGUT4EQJVG65HVTCBF66GDJY4" data-el="text" class="wpds-c-heFNVF wpds-c-heFNVF-iPJLV-css overrideStyles font-copy" dir="null">Still, Weeraratna said, there’s an important public health takeaway.</p></div><div class="wpds-c-PJLV article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-testid="drop-cap-letter" data-apitype="text" data-contentid="GJSXAIWSHZEY5PC2QGNTNSCEYU" data-el="text" class="wpds-c-heFNVF wpds-c-heFNVF-iPJLV-css overrideStyles font-copy" dir="null">“Mitigating risk of infection may be of particular importance for cancer patients,” Weeraratna said. Based on the study’s findings, measures adopted by vulnerable patients starting in the early days of the pandemic — wearing masks, avoiding crowded places, getting vaccines — become even more important.</p></div><div class="wpds-c-PJLV article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-testid="drop-cap-letter" data-apitype="text" data-contentid="OD26BMEPL5D3DGY464CBJHEIFI" data-el="text" class="wpds-c-heFNVF wpds-c-heFNVF-iPJLV-css overrideStyles font-copy" dir="null">Other studies offer telltale clues about the link between viruses and cancer.</p></div><div class="wpds-c-PJLV article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-testid="drop-cap-letter" data-apitype="text" data-contentid="NXIN5FXHERFARN4EAKTFPGCLFQ" data-el="text" class="wpds-c-heFNVF wpds-c-heFNVF-iPJLV-css overrideStyles font-copy" dir="null">Pathologists from the University of Arkansas for Medical Sciences reported in 2021 in the journal <a href="https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/34083759/#full-view-affiliation-1" target=_blank>Communications Biology</a> that SARS-CoV-2 proteins fueled the replication of a herpesvirus considered one of the major viruses leading to cancer. <a href="https://breast-cancer-research.biomedcentral.com/articles/10.1186/s13058-020-01360-0" target=_blank>Other studies</a> have implicated the coronavirus in helping to stimulate dormant breast cancer cells.</p></div><div class="wpds-c-PJLV article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-testid="drop-cap-letter" data-apitype="text" data-contentid="GCZPYKPWO5AEZOV7PGJOUE56I4" data-el="text" class="wpds-c-heFNVF wpds-c-heFNVF-iPJLV-css overrideStyles font-copy" dir="null">A paper published in 2023 in the journal <a href="https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC10202899/?s=09#" target=_blank>Biochimie</a> explored mechanisms the coronavirus could exploit to aggravate several forms of cancer, including lung, colorectal, pancreatic and oral. Researchers suggested the most likely pathway was through disrupting the body’s ability to suppress tumors, but researchers acknowledged a lack of direct evidence to support the theory.</p></div><div class="wpds-c-PJLV article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-testid="drop-cap-letter" data-apitype="text" data-contentid="2N46X5YQLRBMTKZLK3332V2J34" data-el="text" class="wpds-c-heFNVF wpds-c-heFNVF-iPJLV-css overrideStyles font-copy" dir="null">Wallace believes the dearth of hard data on the coronavirus and cancer reflects policy choices more than scientific challenges.</p></div><div class="wpds-c-PJLV article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-testid="drop-cap-letter" data-apitype="text" data-contentid="N5NNFCJBQNCZXK2APPCGCJ3YBY" data-el="text" class="wpds-c-heFNVF wpds-c-heFNVF-iPJLV-css overrideStyles font-copy" dir="null">“I would say most governments don’t want to think about long covid and much less long covid and cancer. It cost them so much to deal with covid. So there is very little funding for the long-term effects of the virus,” he said. “I don’t think that’s a wise choice.”</p></div><div class="wpds-c-PJLV article-body" data-qa="article-body"><h3 data-qa="article-header" data-contentid="JGYMN6HPSRBITKIWFW7CXHG744" data-apitype="header" class=" pb-sm pt-lgmod" id="JGYMN6HPSRBITKIWFW7CXHG744"><div>‘Everyone has it’</div></h3></div><div class="wpds-c-PJLV article-body" data-qa="article-body"><div class="PJLV PJLV-iPJLV-css hide-for-print" data-qa="article-image"><div style="min-height:358px"></div></div></div><div class="wpds-c-PJLV article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-testid="drop-cap-letter" data-apitype="text" data-contentid="W5IBKPT6U5FMHIF43KEWIN6NAA" data-el="text" class="wpds-c-heFNVF wpds-c-heFNVF-iPJLV-css overrideStyles font-copy" dir="null">From his practice in this Southern town, Patel is conducting his own research into what he has taken to calling “an unusual pattern” of cancers. He is driven by watching patients — especially younger ones — die so quickly.</p></div><div class="wpds-c-PJLV article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-testid="drop-cap-letter" data-apitype="text" data-contentid="BSL5WVLOJJDU5KQRNSSJW4QXUU" data-el="text" class="wpds-c-heFNVF wpds-c-heFNVF-iPJLV-css overrideStyles font-copy" dir="null">He’s looking at potential correlations between long-covid markers and unusual cancers. He has collected data from nearly 300 patients and wants to create a national registry to analyze trends. So far, his office has logged more than 15 patients with multiple cancers, more than 35 patients with rare cancers and more than 15 couples with new cancers since the pandemic began in 2020.</p></div><div class="wpds-c-PJLV article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-testid="drop-cap-letter" data-apitype="text" data-contentid="OUESWBIS2JDENORZQMDJXC4CDQ" data-el="text" class="wpds-c-heFNVF wpds-c-heFNVF-iPJLV-css overrideStyles font-copy" dir="null">Patel theorizes the effects of coronavirus infections could be cumulative in people infected multiple times. Pandemic-related stress may compound the threat, he said, by exacerbating inflammation.</p></div><div class="wpds-c-PJLV article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-testid="drop-cap-letter" data-apitype="text" data-contentid="GXIKVBEJENCNTJ7L5ROAZK5CKQ" data-el="text" class="wpds-c-heFNVF wpds-c-heFNVF-iPJLV-css overrideStyles font-copy" dir="null">If a link is established between the virus and cancer, he said, doctors might identify patients at greater risk and implement screenings earlier and even put some patients on anti-inflammatory drugs.</p></div><div class="wpds-c-PJLV article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-testid="drop-cap-letter" data-apitype="text" data-contentid="AI7TAJZ2SNEATJI2HBWKJCBNA4" data-el="text" class="wpds-c-heFNVF wpds-c-heFNVF-iPJLV-css overrideStyles font-copy" dir="null">Mammograms and colonoscopies would have done nothing to prevent the illness of one of Patel’s patients, a 78-year-old diagnosed with three cancers — throat, liver and lungs — within a year.</p></div><div class="wpds-c-PJLV article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-testid="drop-cap-letter" data-apitype="text" data-contentid="LZZXKMAID5DLZLGRY4QMK546UY" data-el="text" class="wpds-c-heFNVF wpds-c-heFNVF-iPJLV-css overrideStyles font-copy" dir="null">Then there’s Bob and Bonnie Krall, a couple who in a 14-month stretch endured three types of cancer between them, despite neither having a family history or genetic predisposition.</p></div><div class="wpds-c-PJLV article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-testid="drop-cap-letter" data-apitype="text" data-contentid="2RH32GV55FDAJADEKGBHBM3FEU" data-el="text" class="wpds-c-heFNVF wpds-c-heFNVF-iPJLV-css overrideStyles font-copy" dir="null">Cancers typically start in one part of the body and spread. It’s rare for discrete cancers to begin in different parts of the body during a short window of time. Patel said the Kralls and the 78-year-old had coronavirus antibodies “through the roof” in their blood although he’s not sure how that relates to cancer, if at all.</p></div><div class="wpds-c-PJLV article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-testid="drop-cap-letter" data-apitype="text" data-contentid="UG23563CJJBEPALUQ3BOXPGO6M" data-el="text" class="wpds-c-heFNVF wpds-c-heFNVF-iPJLV-css overrideStyles font-copy" dir="null">Patel met the Kralls in 2022 when Bob was diagnosed with chronic lymphocytic leukemia, a cancer of the blood and bone marrow. During one of her husband’s treatments, Bonnie mentioned she was dealing with her own health issues related to long covid, including stomach pain. Medications weren’t helping. Patel ran tests and discovered Bonnie had cancer, too. By the time she was scheduled for surgery a few weeks after diagnosis, the malignancy in her abdomen had grown three more centimeters and weighed 8.5 pounds. This year, Bob’s doctors found cancer in his lungs.</p></div><div class="wpds-c-PJLV article-body" data-qa="article-body"><div class="PJLV PJLV-iPJLV-css hide-for-print" data-qa="article-image"><div style="min-height:358px"></div></div></div><div class="wpds-c-PJLV article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-testid="drop-cap-letter" data-apitype="text" data-contentid="YPRPI3FWMNARBBXDJ5AZGGKGGA" data-el="text" class="wpds-c-heFNVF wpds-c-heFNVF-iPJLV-css overrideStyles font-copy" dir="null">Bob’s blood cancer, CLL, is considered rare with only four or five cases in every 100,000 people, but he has been surprised to find four of his neighbors and friends have it, too.</p></div><div class="wpds-c-PJLV article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-testid="drop-cap-letter" data-apitype="text" data-contentid="CEHWADQTEZA37L7B4ZPHEXUCNE" data-el="text" class="wpds-c-heFNVF wpds-c-heFNVF-iPJLV-css overrideStyles font-copy" dir="null">“It’s like a cold. It seems like everyone has it,” said Bob, 73, a flight instructor.</p></div><div class="wpds-c-PJLV article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-testid="drop-cap-letter" data-apitype="text" data-contentid="W5LVAOAL3FFAVIFHVTHAIZR6WY" data-el="text" class="wpds-c-heFNVF wpds-c-heFNVF-iPJLV-css overrideStyles font-copy" dir="null">Even before Patel mentioned his research, Bonnie, 74, who used to work part-time as a front desk assistant and lives with her husband in Fort Mill, S.C., had wondered whether their cancers were related to the coronavirus. She was infected shortly before her cancer diagnosis.</p></div><div class="wpds-c-PJLV article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-testid="drop-cap-letter" data-apitype="text" data-contentid="77KUO27C4FAZVBHVAUYJTZ3TVM" data-el="text" class="wpds-c-heFNVF wpds-c-heFNVF-iPJLV-css overrideStyles font-copy" dir="null">“Maybe if we didn’t get covid …” she started before trailing off. Bob shrugged and finished for her. “Maybe we would have been better? Maybe we would have been worse.”</p></div><div class="wpds-c-PJLV article-body" data-qa="article-body"><div data-qa="correction-disclaimer" class="wpds-c-lgLEQx wpds-c-lgLEQx-iPJLV-css"><div data-testid="disclaimer-headline" class="wpds-c-kAVFVG">correction</div><p data-contentid="EB5KWKHGLBCIPG33VP7AQ6UG54" data-apitype="correction" data-testid="disclaimer-description" class="wpds-c-joLgjs">A previous version of this article incorrectly said Ashani Weeraratna is a physician. She holds a PhD, not an MD. The article has been corrected. </p></div></div></div><div class="wpds-c-jkoBlc wpds-c-jkoBlc-leHWbT-removeAllStyles-true"><div class="wpds-c-dhzjXW wpds-c-dhzjXW-idKpyXE-css overrideStyles test"><div (Kate Medley for The Washington Post)","height":3733,"subtype":"StaffPhoto","type":"image","url":"https://arc-anglerfish-washpost-prod-washpost.s3.amazonaws.com/public/BQCI2AC6QJU7QROSUMPPPKAHRU.jpg","width":5600,"originalIdx":0},{"_id":"5GP33XISTFGSVGQCSLQ3MN7MSI","additional_properties":{},"content":"ROCK HILL, S.C. — Kashyap Patel looked forward to his team’s Friday lunches. All the doctors from his oncology practice would gather in the open-air courtyard under the shadow of a tall magnolia tree and catch up. The atmosphere tended to the lighthearted and optimistic. But that week, he was distressed.","type":"text","originalIdx":1},{"_id":"6RTNG6QDX5E65LIJ7YOLRQ3YGU","additional_properties":{},"content":"It was 2021, a year into the \u003ca href=\"https://www.washingtonpost.com/coronavirus/\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"contextual_link\"\u003ecoronavirus\u003c/a\u003e pandemic, and as he slid into a chair, Patel shared that he’d just seen a patient in his 40s with cholangiocarcinoma, a rare and lethal cancer of the bile ducts that typically strikes people in their 70s and 80s. Initially, there was silence, and then one colleague after another said they’d recently treated patients who had similar diagnoses. Within a year of that meeting, the office had recorded seven such cases.","type":"text","originalIdx":2},{"_id":"UZT7FI5LRZDFRDWVEOKZDWVF5U","additional_properties":{},"content":"“I’ve been in practice 23 years and have never seen anything like this,” Patel, CEO of Carolina Blood and Cancer Care Associates, later recalled. Asutosh Gor, another oncologist, agreed: “We were all shaken.”","type":"text","originalIdx":3},{"_id":"XJ5ONUNUXBGVPI5VLQ65EV7PCI","additional_properties":{},"content":"There was other weirdness, too: multiple patients contending with multiple types of cancer arising almost simultaneously, and more than a dozen new cases of other rare cancers.","type":"text","originalIdx":4},{"_id":"6JIPCV5X5RD2TBWD5O2SGLBH7I","additional_properties":{},"content":"Increasingly, Patel was left with an unsettling thought: Could the coronavirus be inflaming\u003cb\u003e \u003c/b\u003ethe embers of cancer?","type":"text","originalIdx":5},{"_id":"GCITCWGVTJBMRPGN6WUUQZIVS4","additional_properties":{},"content":"The uptick in aggressive, late-stage cancers since the dawn of the pandemic is confirmed by some early national data and a number of large cancer institutions. Many experts have mostly dismissed the trend as an expected consequence of disruptions to health care that began in 2020.","type":"text","originalIdx":6},{"_id":"7GJTV6SRJZDW3HGQQWY5J2BDHU","additional_properties":{},"content":"But not everyone.","type":"text","originalIdx":7},{"_id":"FSN6IPU7DBDSNLJVZK43ZDQM74","additional_properties":{},"content":"The idea that some viruses can cause or accelerate cancer is hardly new. Scientists have recognized this possibility since the 1960s, and today, researchers estimate 15 to 20 percent of all cancers worldwide originate from infectious agents such as HPV, Epstein-Barr and hepatitis B.","type":"text","originalIdx":8},{"_id":"MGADNGJBRBFFFEQLHTAC7OAEHA","additional_properties":{},"content":"It will probably be many years before the world has conclusive answers about whether the coronavirus is complicit in the surge of cancer cases, but Patel and other concerned scientists are calling on the U.S. government to make this question a priority knowing it could affect treatment and management of millions of cancer patients for decades to come.","type":"text","originalIdx":9},{"_id":"OAJBVGHGV5HYFK6YSJZ5FNCIDQ","additional_properties":{},"content":"“We are completely under-investigating this virus,” said Douglas C. Wallace, a University of Pennsylvania geneticist and evolutionary biologist. “The effects of repeatedly getting this throughout our lives is going to be much more significant than people are thinking.”","type":"text","originalIdx":10},{"_id":"L3US3MYFJ4MPHXAJDL4ZEILLRY","additional_properties":{"size_normalized_url":"https://arc-anglerfish-washpost-prod-washpost.s3.amazonaws.com/public/L3US3MYFJ4MPHXAJDL4ZEILLRY_size-normalized.jpg","media_size":"medium"},"credits":{"by":[{"name":"Kate Medley"}]},"alt_text":"","credits_caption_display":"Patel visits with caregiver Meggie Sullivan in April about her husband’s cancer diagnosis. (Kate Medley for The Washington Post)","height":3710,"subtype":"StaffPhoto","type":"image","url":"https://arc-anglerfish-washpost-prod-washpost.s3.amazonaws.com/public/L3US3MYFJ4MPHXAJDL4ZEILLRY.jpg","width":5600,"originalIdx":11},{"_id":"A3IKXRAEBREQ5GGZN2EHIR35LM","additional_properties":{},"content":"But there is no real world data linking SARS-CoV-2 to cancer, and some scientists remain\u003cb\u003e \u003c/b\u003eskeptical.","type":"text","originalIdx":12},{"_id":"6Q7H63VHPVGETGCJL4W75UKBCI","additional_properties":{},"content":"John T. Schiller, a National Institutes of Health researcher and pioneer in the study of cancer-causing viruses, said pathogens known to cause cancer persist in the body long-term. But the class of respiratory viruses that includes influenza and RSV — a family that counts the coronavirus as a member — infects a patient and then typically goes away instead of lingering and is not believed to cause cancer.","type":"text","originalIdx":13},{"_id":"Y6V7PAEEFNEBDNKMZEBR2NAPV4","additional_properties":{},"content":"“You can never say never, but that sort of … virus does not suggest being implicated in cancers,” Schiller said.","type":"text","originalIdx":14},{"_id":"BPK3AF7PSZDR5BAFBRV7B6PEGM","additional_properties":{},"content":"David Tuveson, director of the Cancer Center at Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory and former president of the American Association for Cancer Research, said there’s no evidence the coronavirus directly transforms cells to make them cancerous. But that may not be the full story.","type":"text","originalIdx":15},{"_id":"B2DMIDK4X5DTXBP567FZVCIHAA","additional_properties":{},"content":"Tuveson said a number of small and early studies — many of which have been published within the past nine months — suggests that coronavirus infection can induce an inflammatory cascade and other responses that, in theory, could exacerbate the growth of cancer cells.","type":"text","originalIdx":16},{"_id":"V7BQVFU3UNBXHIQMX6IK6P6FR4","additional_properties":{},"content":"He has wondered whether it could be more akin to an environmental stressor — like tobacco, alcohol, asbestos or microplastics.","type":"text","originalIdx":17},{"_id":"ESYYTSTBBVCEHFO7GG6WKFUBRA","additional_properties":{},"content":"“Covid wrecks the body, and that’s where cancers can start,” Tuveson said, explaining how autopsy studies of people who died of covid-19 showed prematurely aged tissue.","type":"text","originalIdx":18},{"_id":"WXNY43XNIFBK7IC6PZSS57OTJU","additional_properties":{},"content":"Even as the first wave of the coronavirus pummeled the United States, public health officials predicted a surge of cancer cases. A \u003ca href=\"https://www.thelancet.com/pdfs/journals/lanonc/PIIS1470-2045(23)00293-0.pdf\" target=_blank\u003eLancet Oncology\u003c/a\u003e paper analyzed a national registry showing increases of Stage 4 disease — the most severe — across many cancer types in late 2020. \u003ca href=\"https://doi.org/10.1016/j.amjsurg.2023.09.040\" target=_blank\u003eBaptist Health Miami Cancer Institute\u003c/a\u003e, \u003ca href=\"https://jamanetwork.com/journals/jamanetworkopen/fullarticle/2789064\" target=_blank\u003eUC San Diego Health\u003c/a\u003e and other large institutions have released data showing continued increases in late-stage cancers.","type":"text","originalIdx":19},{"_id":"JFBVHRTDIBBZBDKGSG4VFXUB2Q","additional_properties":{},"content":"Xuesong Han, scientific director of health services research at the American Cancer Society and lead author of the Lancet Oncology study, attributed the jump to people delaying or skipping care because of fears related to the virus or because of economic reasons and also to cultural factors, language barriers and discrimination. But Han acknowledged that biological mechanisms of SARS-CoV-2, the virus that causes covid-19, could be at play.","type":"text","originalIdx":20},{"_id":"ITVV5ZZNFFHDXNWMPRVRXUP4TA","additional_properties":{},"content":"“I don’t have the data to support this opinion,” Han said. “But it’s an important question to follow up on.”","type":"text","originalIdx":21},{"_id":"UYWREWS5FFCDBFGOLNJWWIAMHI","additional_properties":{},"content":"‘Hopefully, we’re wrong’","level":3,"type":"header","originalIdx":22},{"_id":"YI7AYKVUUOZQE22NW5C63VDE64","additional_properties":{"size_normalized_url":"https://arc-anglerfish-washpost-prod-washpost.s3.amazonaws.com/public/YI7AYKVUUOZQE22NW5C63VDE64_size-normalized.jpg","media_size":"medium"},"credits":{"by":[{"name":"Kate Medley"}]},"alt_text":"","credits_caption_display":"Patel is helping preside over research studies trying to piece together the puzzle of coronavirus infection, long covid and cancer. (Kate Medley for The Washington Post)","height":3733,"subtype":"StaffPhoto","type":"image","url":"https://arc-anglerfish-washpost-prod-washpost.s3.amazonaws.com/public/YI7AYKVUUOZQE22NW5C63VDE64.jpg","width":5600,"originalIdx":23},{"_id":"ONWM27UH55GRVKRPNBLSEQTIAI","additional_properties":{},"content":"The human body is made up of trillions of cells in a constant state of growth, repair and death. Most of the time, cells with damaged DNA fix themselves, or simply disappear. Sometimes, they start collecting mistakes in their genetic code and rampage out of control into tumors, destroying parts of the body.","type":"text","originalIdx":24},{"_id":"QTP4EMDVPRC2NH54BP52XQJ2EI","additional_properties":{},"content":"Afshin Beheshti is president of the COVID-19 International Research Team, a group of scientists from eclectic backgrounds who got together during the pandemic to consider out-of-the-box of ways to tackle the virus. Beheshti’s background is in cancer biology, and he said that as the science on the virus evolved — including studies showing widespread inflammation following infection, impact on the vascular system and infection in multiple organs vulnerable to cancer stem cell development — he kept thinking “the signals seemed to be related to early cancer changes.”","type":"text","originalIdx":25},{"_id":"RCTSW3PXLNCMRM7F2AWOKZYD7Q","additional_properties":{},"content":"“It kept nagging on my mind,” he said.","type":"text","originalIdx":26},{"_id":"PELHVIKWT5CCXBJEWBUBVBD2XY","additional_properties":{},"content":"About a year ago Beheshti, a visiting researcher at MIT and Harvard’s Broad Institute, reached out to Patel, who is a past president of the Community Oncology Alliance, a national group of independent cancer specialists, and they hosted a symposium with other scientists that concluded compelling evidence exists suggesting links between the coronavirus and cancer.","type":"text","originalIdx":27},{"_id":"N3FAILF6T5DLLPTSKWACUZWSSQ","additional_properties":{},"content":"“Hopefully, we’re wrong,” Beheshti said. “But everything is, unfortunately, pushing toward that being the case.”","type":"text","originalIdx":28},{"_id":"IVYNSHIMDZBF5F3AQYEV6YOVPE","additional_properties":{},"content":"The group’s loosely affiliated members are launching research studies that are trying to piece together the puzzle of coronavirus infection, long covid and cancer.","type":"text","originalIdx":29},{"_id":"HTCOFZNVAZEZNIEQ5KHA7LCL6E","additional_properties":{},"content":"Wallace — the University of Pennsylvania scientist considered a father of the field of human mitochondrial genetics, which explores the power plants that fuel human cells — is researching how covid affects energy production in cells and how that might influence cancer vulnerability.","type":"text","originalIdx":30},{"_id":"UUU4DH2V6BBT5CFDNIQYDA76GA","additional_properties":{},"content":"Separately, biodata experts are sequencing the gene profiles of organs from people who succumbed to covid and underwent autopsies.","type":"text","originalIdx":31},{"_id":"PM2G3IDJQVHQBJ3ISVB6HPIDEQ","additional_properties":{},"content":"And a University of Colorado team is studying whether covid reawakens dormant cancer cells in mice. Their provocative findings, according to a \u003ca href=\"https://www.researchsquare.com/article/rs-4210090/v1\" target=_blank\u003epreprint\u003c/a\u003e report released in April, showed that when mice that were cancer survivors were infected with SARS-CoV-2, dormant cancer cells proliferated in the lungs. They saw similar results with the flu virus.","type":"text","originalIdx":32},{"_id":"6CWJGB6LGFFJZOURZ6NXUSG2MA","additional_properties":{},"content":"Ashani Weeraratna, a professor at the Johns Hopkins Bloomberg School of Public Health, said the Colorado study, which she did not participate in, is part of a new field of work that emerged during the past decade that drills into what stimuli can reawaken cancer cells.","type":"text","originalIdx":33},{"_id":"DJDQQ74ABRGIHCAEIKBDMDEDA4","additional_properties":{},"content":"She said it is consistent with research highlighting the importance of the immune system in activating cells from dormancy, so it makes sense that “something like influenza or covid that triggers inflammation could change in the immune microenvironment.” But the results surprised her because “it’s rare the data are so striking.”","type":"text","originalIdx":34},{"_id":"KZHGGFMFOOX3E4W6QWTE3ABJ7A","additional_properties":{"size_normalized_url":"https://arc-anglerfish-washpost-prod-washpost.s3.amazonaws.com/public/KZHGGFMFOOX3E4W6QWTE3ABJ7A_size-normalized.jpg","media_size":"medium"},"credits":{"by":[{"name":"Kate Medley"}]},"alt_text":"","credits_caption_display":"Bonnie and Bob Krall endured three types of cancer between them in a 14-month stretch, despite neither having a family history or genetic predisposition. But they both had covid. (Kate Medley for The Washington Post)","height":3774,"subtype":"StaffPhoto","type":"image","url":"https://arc-anglerfish-washpost-prod-washpost.s3.amazonaws.com/public/KZHGGFMFOOX3E4W6QWTE3ABJ7A.jpg","width":5600,"originalIdx":35},{"_id":"M2TFQPUNFFDIFA7QTKL4BHUFDQ","additional_properties":{},"content":"Weeraratna said that while she believes the Colorado study’s findings are important, they should be interpreted with caution. Studies in mice often do not translate to human experiences. She said it’s also important to emphasize that the research and other recent papers focusing on covid and cancer involve acute infection or long covid; they do not suggest a link between the coronavirus vaccine and cancer — misinformation that some anti-vaccine groups have spread in recent months.","type":"text","originalIdx":36},{"_id":"OTGUT4EQJVG65HVTCBF66GDJY4","additional_properties":{},"content":"Still, Weeraratna said, there’s an important public health takeaway.","type":"text","originalIdx":37},{"_id":"GJSXAIWSHZEY5PC2QGNTNSCEYU","additional_properties":{},"content":"“Mitigating risk of infection may be of particular importance for cancer patients,” Weeraratna said. Based on the study’s findings, measures adopted by vulnerable patients starting in the early days of the pandemic — wearing masks, avoiding crowded places, getting vaccines — become even more important.","type":"text","originalIdx":38},{"_id":"OD26BMEPL5D3DGY464CBJHEIFI","additional_properties":{},"content":"Other studies offer telltale clues about the link between viruses and cancer.","type":"text","originalIdx":39},{"_id":"NXIN5FXHERFARN4EAKTFPGCLFQ","additional_properties":{},"content":"Pathologists from the University of Arkansas for Medical Sciences reported in 2021 in the journal \u003ca href=\"https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/34083759/#full-view-affiliation-1\" target=_blank\u003eCommunications Biology\u003c/a\u003e that SARS-CoV-2 proteins fueled the replication of a herpesvirus considered one of the major viruses leading to cancer. \u003ca href=\"https://breast-cancer-research.biomedcentral.com/articles/10.1186/s13058-020-01360-0\" target=_blank\u003eOther studies\u003c/a\u003e have implicated the coronavirus in helping to stimulate dormant breast cancer cells.","type":"text","originalIdx":40},{"_id":"GCZPYKPWO5AEZOV7PGJOUE56I4","additional_properties":{},"content":"A paper published in 2023 in the journal \u003ca href=\"https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC10202899/?s=09#\" target=_blank\u003eBiochimie\u003c/a\u003e explored mechanisms the coronavirus could exploit to aggravate several forms of cancer, including lung, colorectal, pancreatic and oral. Researchers suggested the most likely pathway was through disrupting the body’s ability to suppress tumors, but researchers acknowledged a lack of direct evidence to support the theory.","type":"text","originalIdx":41},{"_id":"2N46X5YQLRBMTKZLK3332V2J34","additional_properties":{},"content":"Wallace believes the dearth of hard data on the coronavirus and cancer reflects policy choices more than scientific challenges.","type":"text","originalIdx":42},{"_id":"N5NNFCJBQNCZXK2APPCGCJ3YBY","additional_properties":{},"content":"“I would say most governments don’t want to think about long covid and much less long covid and cancer. It cost them so much to deal with covid. So there is very little funding for the long-term effects of the virus,” he said. “I don’t think that’s a wise choice.”","type":"text","originalIdx":43},{"_id":"JGYMN6HPSRBITKIWFW7CXHG744","additional_properties":{},"content":"‘Everyone has it’","level":3,"type":"header","originalIdx":44},{"_id":"NFYGYBAQMFGCAGAV4FRQ3G7HOI","additional_properties":{"size_normalized_url":"https://arc-anglerfish-washpost-prod-washpost.s3.amazonaws.com/public/NFYGYBAQMFGCAGAV4FRQ3G7HOI_size-normalized.jpg","media_size":"medium"},"credits":{"by":[{"name":"Kate Medley"}]},"alt_text":"","credits_caption_display":"The Kralls enjoy riding their electric bikes around their neighborhood in South Carolina. (Kate Medley for The Washington Post)","height":3226,"subtype":"StaffPhoto","type":"image","url":"https://arc-anglerfish-washpost-prod-washpost.s3.amazonaws.com/public/NFYGYBAQMFGCAGAV4FRQ3G7HOI.jpg","width":4696,"originalIdx":45},{"_id":"W5IBKPT6U5FMHIF43KEWIN6NAA","additional_properties":{},"content":"From his practice in this Southern town, Patel is conducting his own research into what he has taken to calling “an unusual pattern” of cancers. He is driven by watching patients — especially younger ones — die so quickly.","type":"text","originalIdx":46},{"_id":"BSL5WVLOJJDU5KQRNSSJW4QXUU","additional_properties":{},"content":"He’s looking at potential correlations between long-covid markers and unusual cancers. He has collected data from nearly 300 patients and wants to create a national registry to analyze trends. So far, his office has logged more than 15 patients with multiple cancers, more than 35 patients with rare cancers and more than 15 couples with new cancers since the pandemic began in 2020.","type":"text","originalIdx":47},{"_id":"OUESWBIS2JDENORZQMDJXC4CDQ","additional_properties":{},"content":"Patel theorizes the effects of coronavirus infections could be cumulative in people infected multiple times. Pandemic-related stress may compound the threat, he said, by exacerbating inflammation.","type":"text","originalIdx":48},{"_id":"GXIKVBEJENCNTJ7L5ROAZK5CKQ","additional_properties":{},"content":"If a link is established between the virus and cancer, he said, doctors might identify patients at greater risk and implement screenings earlier and even put some patients on anti-inflammatory drugs.","type":"text","originalIdx":49},{"_id":"AI7TAJZ2SNEATJI2HBWKJCBNA4","additional_properties":{},"content":"Mammograms and colonoscopies would have done nothing to prevent the illness of one of Patel’s patients, a 78-year-old diagnosed with three cancers — throat, liver and lungs — within a year.","type":"text","originalIdx":50},{"_id":"LZZXKMAID5DLZLGRY4QMK546UY","additional_properties":{},"content":"Then there’s Bob and Bonnie Krall, a couple who in a 14-month stretch endured three types of cancer between them, despite neither having a family history or genetic predisposition.","type":"text","originalIdx":51},{"_id":"2RH32GV55FDAJADEKGBHBM3FEU","additional_properties":{},"content":"Cancers typically start in one part of the body and spread. It’s rare for discrete cancers to begin in different parts of the body during a short window of time. Patel said the Kralls and the 78-year-old had coronavirus antibodies “through the roof” in their blood although he’s not sure how that relates to cancer, if at all.","type":"text","originalIdx":52},{"_id":"UG23563CJJBEPALUQ3BOXPGO6M","additional_properties":{},"content":"Patel met the Kralls in 2022 when Bob was diagnosed with chronic lymphocytic leukemia, a cancer of the blood and bone marrow. During one of her husband’s treatments, Bonnie mentioned she was dealing with her own health issues related to long covid, including stomach pain. Medications weren’t helping. Patel ran tests and discovered Bonnie had cancer, too. By the time she was scheduled for surgery a few weeks after diagnosis, the malignancy in her abdomen had grown three more centimeters and weighed 8.5 pounds. This year, Bob’s doctors found cancer in his lungs.","type":"text","originalIdx":53},{"_id":"RTIBIL7IPEWDVJIU73EURSBVLY","additional_properties":{"size_normalized_url":"https://arc-anglerfish-washpost-prod-washpost.s3.amazonaws.com/public/RTIBIL7IPEWDVJIU73EURSBVLY_size-normalized.jpg","media_size":"medium"},"credits":{"by":[{"name":"Kate Medley"}]},"alt_text":"","credits_caption_display":"The Kralls had coronavirus antibodies “through the roof” in their blood although Patel says he’s not sure how that relates to cancer, if at all. (Kate Medley for The Washington Post)","height":3795,"subtype":"StaffPhoto","type":"image","url":"https://arc-anglerfish-washpost-prod-washpost.s3.amazonaws.com/public/RTIBIL7IPEWDVJIU73EURSBVLY.jpg","width":5600,"originalIdx":54},{"_id":"YPRPI3FWMNARBBXDJ5AZGGKGGA","additional_properties":{},"content":"Bob’s blood cancer, CLL, is considered rare with only four or five cases in every 100,000 people, but he has been surprised to find four of his neighbors and friends have it, too.","type":"text","originalIdx":55},{"_id":"CEHWADQTEZA37L7B4ZPHEXUCNE","additional_properties":{},"content":"“It’s like a cold. It seems like everyone has it,” said Bob, 73, a flight instructor.","type":"text","originalIdx":56},{"_id":"W5LVAOAL3FFAVIFHVTHAIZR6WY","additional_properties":{},"content":"Even before Patel mentioned his research, Bonnie, 74, who used to work part-time as a front desk assistant and lives with her husband in Fort Mill, S.C., had wondered whether their cancers were related to the coronavirus. She was infected shortly before her cancer diagnosis.","type":"text","originalIdx":57},{"_id":"77KUO27C4FAZVBHVAUYJTZ3TVM","additional_properties":{},"content":"“Maybe if we didn’t get covid …” she started before trailing off. Bob shrugged and finished for her. “Maybe we would have been better? Maybe we would have been worse.”","type":"text","originalIdx":58},{"_id":"EB5KWKHGLBCIPG33VP7AQ6UG54","additional_properties":{},"correction_type":"correction","text":"A previous version of this article incorrectly said Ashani Weeraratna is a physician. readabilityObject.title: ‘Unusual’ cancers emerged after the pandemic. Doctors ask if covid is to blame.
readabilityObject.content:
ROCK HILL, S.C. — Kashyap Patel looked forward to his team’s Friday lunches. All the doctors from his oncology practice would gather in the open-air courtyard under the shadow of a tall magnolia tree and catch up. The atmosphere tended to the lighthearted and optimistic. But that week, he was distressed.

It was 2021, a year into the coronavirus pandemic, and as he slid into a chair, Patel shared that he’d just seen a patient in his 40s with cholangiocarcinoma, a rare and lethal cancer of the bile ducts that typically strikes people in their 70s and 80s. Initially, there was silence, and then one colleague after another said they’d recently treated patients who had similar diagnoses. Within a year of that meeting, the office had recorded seven such cases.

“I’ve been in practice 23 years and have never seen anything like this,” Patel, CEO of Carolina Blood and Cancer Care Associates, later recalled. Asutosh Gor, another oncologist, agreed: “We were all shaken.”

There was other weirdness, too: multiple patients contending with multiple types of cancer arising almost simultaneously, and more than a dozen new cases of other rare cancers.

Increasingly, Patel was left with an unsettling thought: Could the coronavirus be inflaming the embers of cancer?

The uptick in aggressive, late-stage cancers since the dawn of the pandemic is confirmed by some early national data and a number of large cancer institutions. Many experts have mostly dismissed the trend as an expected consequence of disruptions to health care that began in 2020.

But not everyone.

The idea that some viruses can cause or accelerate cancer is hardly new. Scientists have recognized this possibility since the 1960s, and today, researchers estimate 15 to 20 percent of all cancers worldwide originate from infectious agents such as HPV, Epstein-Barr and hepatitis B.

It will probably be many years before the world has conclusive answers about whether the coronavirus is complicit in the surge of cancer cases, but Patel and other concerned scientists are calling on the U.S. government to make this question a priority knowing it could affect treatment and management of millions of cancer patients for decades to come.

“We are completely under-investigating this virus,” said Douglas C. Wallace, a University of Pennsylvania geneticist and evolutionary biologist. “The effects of repeatedly getting this throughout our lives is going to be much more significant than people are thinking.”

But there is no real world data linking SARS-CoV-2 to cancer, and some scientists remain skeptical.

John T. Schiller, a National Institutes of Health researcher and pioneer in the study of cancer-causing viruses, said pathogens known to cause cancer persist in the body long-term. But the class of respiratory viruses that includes influenza and RSV — a family that counts the coronavirus as a member — infects a patient and then typically goes away instead of lingering and is not believed to cause cancer.

“You can never say never, but that sort of … virus does not suggest being implicated in cancers,” Schiller said.

David Tuveson, director of the Cancer Center at Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory and former president of the American Association for Cancer Research, said there’s no evidence the coronavirus directly transforms cells to make them cancerous. But that may not be the full story.

Tuveson said a number of small and early studies — many of which have been published within the past nine months — suggests that coronavirus infection can induce an inflammatory cascade and other responses that, in theory, could exacerbate the growth of cancer cells.

He has wondered whether it could be more akin to an environmental stressor — like tobacco, alcohol, asbestos or microplastics.

“Covid wrecks the body, and that’s where cancers can start,” Tuveson said, explaining how autopsy studies of people who died of covid-19 showed prematurely aged tissue.

Even as the first wave of the coronavirus pummeled the United States, public health officials predicted a surge of cancer cases. A Lancet Oncology paper analyzed a national registry showing increases of Stage 4 disease — the most severe — across many cancer types in late 2020. Baptist Health Miami Cancer Institute, UC San Diego Health and other large institutions have released data showing continued increases in late-stage cancers.

Xuesong Han, scientific director of health services research at the American Cancer Society and lead author of the Lancet Oncology study, attributed the jump to people delaying or skipping care because of fears related to the virus or because of economic reasons and also to cultural factors, language barriers and discrimination. But Han acknowledged that biological mechanisms of SARS-CoV-2, the virus that causes covid-19, could be at play.

“I don’t have the data to support this opinion,” Han said. “But it’s an important question to follow up on.”

‘Hopefully, we’re wrong’

The human body is made up of trillions of cells in a constant state of growth, repair and death. Most of the time, cells with damaged DNA fix themselves, or simply disappear. Sometimes, they start collecting mistakes in their genetic code and rampage out of control into tumors, destroying parts of the body.

Afshin Beheshti is president of the COVID-19 International Research Team, a group of scientists from eclectic backgrounds who got together during the pandemic to consider out-of-the-box of ways to tackle the virus. Beheshti’s background is in cancer biology, and he said that as the science on the virus evolved — including studies showing widespread inflammation following infection, impact on the vascular system and infection in multiple organs vulnerable to cancer stem cell development — he kept thinking “the signals seemed to be related to early cancer changes.”

“It kept nagging on my mind,” he said.

About a year ago Beheshti, a visiting researcher at MIT and Harvard’s Broad Institute, reached out to Patel, who is a past president of the Community Oncology Alliance, a national group of independent cancer specialists, and they hosted a symposium with other scientists that concluded compelling evidence exists suggesting links between the coronavirus and cancer.

“Hopefully, we’re wrong,” Beheshti said. “But everything is, unfortunately, pushing toward that being the case.”

The group’s loosely affiliated members are launching research studies that are trying to piece together the puzzle of coronavirus infection, long covid and cancer.

Wallace — the University of Pennsylvania scientist considered a father of the field of human mitochondrial genetics, which explores the power plants that fuel human cells — is researching how covid affects energy production in cells and how that might influence cancer vulnerability.

Separately, biodata experts are sequencing the gene profiles of organs from people who succumbed to covid and underwent autopsies.

And a University of Colorado team is studying whether covid reawakens dormant cancer cells in mice. Their provocative findings, according to a preprint report released in April, showed that when mice that were cancer survivors were infected with SARS-CoV-2, dormant cancer cells proliferated in the lungs. They saw similar results with the flu virus.

Ashani Weeraratna, a professor at the Johns Hopkins Bloomberg School of Public Health, said the Colorado study, which she did not participate in, is part of a new field of work that emerged during the past decade that drills into what stimuli can reawaken cancer cells.

She said it is consistent with research highlighting the importance of the immune system in activating cells from dormancy, so it makes sense that “something like influenza or covid that triggers inflammation could change in the immune microenvironment.” But the results surprised her because “it’s rare the data are so striking.”

Weeraratna said that while she believes the Colorado study’s findings are important, they should be interpreted with caution. Studies in mice often do not translate to human experiences. She said it’s also important to emphasize that the research and other recent papers focusing on covid and cancer involve acute infection or long covid; they do not suggest a link between the coronavirus vaccine and cancer — misinformation that some anti-vaccine groups have spread in recent months.

Still, Weeraratna said, there’s an important public health takeaway.

“Mitigating risk of infection may be of particular importance for cancer patients,” Weeraratna said. Based on the study’s findings, measures adopted by vulnerable patients starting in the early days of the pandemic — wearing masks, avoiding crowded places, getting vaccines — become even more important.

Other studies offer telltale clues about the link between viruses and cancer.

Pathologists from the University of Arkansas for Medical Sciences reported in 2021 in the journal Communications Biology that SARS-CoV-2 proteins fueled the replication of a herpesvirus considered one of the major viruses leading to cancer. Other studies have implicated the coronavirus in helping to stimulate dormant breast cancer cells.

A paper published in 2023 in the journal Biochimie explored mechanisms the coronavirus could exploit to aggravate several forms of cancer, including lung, colorectal, pancreatic and oral. Researchers suggested the most likely pathway was through disrupting the body’s ability to suppress tumors, but researchers acknowledged a lack of direct evidence to support the theory.

Wallace believes the dearth of hard data on the coronavirus and cancer reflects policy choices more than scientific challenges.

“I would say most governments don’t want to think about long covid and much less long covid and cancer. It cost them so much to deal with covid. So there is very little funding for the long-term effects of the virus,” he said. “I don’t think that’s a wise choice.”

‘Everyone has it’

From his practice in this Southern town, Patel is conducting his own research into what he has taken to calling “an unusual pattern” of cancers. He is driven by watching patients — especially younger ones — die so quickly.

He’s looking at potential correlations between long-covid markers and unusual cancers. He has collected data from nearly 300 patients and wants to create a national registry to analyze trends. So far, his office has logged more than 15 patients with multiple cancers, more than 35 patients with rare cancers and more than 15 couples with new cancers since the pandemic began in 2020.

Patel theorizes the effects of coronavirus infections could be cumulative in people infected multiple times. Pandemic-related stress may compound the threat, he said, by exacerbating inflammation.

If a link is established between the virus and cancer, he said, doctors might identify patients at greater risk and implement screenings earlier and even put some patients on anti-inflammatory drugs.

Mammograms and colonoscopies would have done nothing to prevent the illness of one of Patel’s patients, a 78-year-old diagnosed with three cancers — throat, liver and lungs — within a year.

Then there’s Bob and Bonnie Krall, a couple who in a 14-month stretch endured three types of cancer between them, despite neither having a family history or genetic predisposition.

Cancers typically start in one part of the body and spread. It’s rare for discrete cancers to begin in different parts of the body during a short window of time. Patel said the Kralls and the 78-year-old had coronavirus antibodies “through the roof” in their blood although he’s not sure how that relates to cancer, if at all.

Patel met the Kralls in 2022 when Bob was diagnosed with chronic lymphocytic leukemia, a cancer of the blood and bone marrow. During one of her husband’s treatments, Bonnie mentioned she was dealing with her own health issues related to long covid, including stomach pain. Medications weren’t helping. Patel ran tests and discovered Bonnie had cancer, too. By the time she was scheduled for surgery a few weeks after diagnosis, the malignancy in her abdomen had grown three more centimeters and weighed 8.5 pounds. This year, Bob’s doctors found cancer in his lungs.

Bob’s blood cancer, CLL, is considered rare with only four or five cases in every 100,000 people, but he has been surprised to find four of his neighbors and friends have it, too.

“It’s like a cold. It seems like everyone has it,” said Bob, 73, a flight instructor.

Even before Patel mentioned his research, Bonnie, 74, who used to work part-time as a front desk assistant and lives with her husband in Fort Mill, S.C., had wondered whether their cancers were related to the coronavirus. She was infected shortly before her cancer diagnosis.

“Maybe if we didn’t get covid …” she started before trailing off. Bob shrugged and finished for her. “Maybe we would have been better? Maybe we would have been worse.”

correction

A previous version of this article incorrectly said Ashani Weeraratna is a physician. She holds a PhD, not an MD. The article has been corrected.

Studies in mice often do not translate to human experiences. Based on the study’s findings, measures adopted by vulnerable patients starting in the early days of the pandemic — wearing masks, avoiding crowded places, getting vaccines — become even more important.Other studies offer telltale clues about the link between viruses and cancer.Pathologists from the University of Arkansas for Medical Sciences reported in 2021 in the journal Communications Biology that SARS-CoV-2 proteins fueled the replication of a herpesvirus considered one of the major viruses leading to cancer. Other studies have implicated the coronavirus in helping to stimulate dormant breast cancer cells.A paper published in 2023 in the journal Biochimie explored mechanisms the coronavirus could exploit to aggravate several forms of cancer, including lung, colorectal, pancreatic and oral. Researchers suggested the most likely pathway was through disrupting the body’s ability to suppress tumors, but researchers acknowledged a lack of direct evidence to support the theory.Wallace believes the dearth of hard data on the coronavirus and cancer reflects policy choices more than scientific challenges.“I would say most governments don’t want to think about long covid and much less long covid and cancer. It cost them so much to deal with covid. So there is very little funding for the long-term effects of the virus,” he said. “I don’t think that’s a wise choice.”‘Everyone has it’From his practice in this Southern town, Patel is conducting his own research into what he has taken to calling “an unusual pattern” of cancers. He is driven by watching patients — especially younger ones — die so quickly.He’s looking at potential correlations between long-covid markers and unusual cancers. He has collected data from nearly 300 patients and wants to create a national registry to analyze trends. So far, his office has logged more than 15 patients with multiple cancers, more than 35 patients with rare cancers and more than 15 couples with new cancers since the pandemic began in 2020.Patel theorizes the effects of coronavirus infections could be cumulative in people infected multiple times. Pandemic-related stress may compound the threat, he said, by exacerbating inflammation.If a link is established between the virus and cancer, he said, doctors might identify patients at greater risk and implement screenings earlier and even put some patients on anti-inflammatory drugs.Mammograms and colonoscopies would have done nothing to prevent the illness of one of Patel’s patients, a 78-year-old diagnosed with three cancers — throat, liver and lungs — within a year.Then there’s Bob and Bonnie Krall, a couple who in a 14-month stretch endured three types of cancer between them, despite neither having a family history or genetic predisposition.Cancers typically start in one part of the body and spread. It’s rare for discrete cancers to begin in different parts of the body during a short window of time. Patel said the Kralls and the 78-year-old had coronavirus antibodies “through the roof” in their blood although he’s not sure how that relates to cancer, if at all.Patel met the Kralls in 2022 when Bob was diagnosed with chronic lymphocytic leukemia, a cancer of the blood and bone marrow. During one of her husband’s treatments, Bonnie mentioned she was dealing with her own health issues related to long covid, including stomach pain. Medications weren’t helping. Patel ran tests and discovered Bonnie had cancer, too. By the time she was scheduled for surgery a few weeks after diagnosis, the malignancy in her abdomen had grown three more centimeters and weighed 8.5 pounds. This year, Bob’s doctors found cancer in his lungs.Bob’s blood cancer, CLL, is considered rare with only four or five cases in every 100,000 people, but he has been surprised to find four of his neighbors and friends have it, too.“It’s like a cold. It seems like everyone has it,” said Bob, 73, a flight instructor.Even before Patel mentioned his research, Bonnie, 74, who used to work part-time as a front desk assistant and lives with her husband in Fort Mill, S.C., had wondered whether their cancers were related to the coronavirus. She was infected shortly before her cancer diagnosis.“Maybe if we didn’t get covid …” she started before trailing off. Bob shrugged and finished for her. “Maybe we would have been better? Maybe we would have been worse.”correctionA previous version of this article incorrectly said Ashani Weeraratna is a physician. She holds a PhD, not an MD. The article has been corrected.
readabilityObject.excerpt: It’s not a new idea that viruses can cause or accelerate cancer. But it will probably be years before answers emerge about covid and cancer.
